In many developed countries, there is a ritual called municipal refuse collection where rubbish bags or the contents of rubbish bins disappear into a lorry and are carried away to the local tip. This ceremony is peculiar because in most places, it is free. However, the cost of rubbish disposal is not zero. If rubbish disposal is free, people will produce too much rubbish. To reduce the amount of rubbish produced, people would have to buy less of just about everything.
A tax of a few cents on the week's garbage seems unlikely to make much difference. If that's the case, it seems worth considering whether other factors, such as income and education, matter every bit as much as price.

Work can be a fulfilling and meaningful experience, but it is not always the case. Many people feel undervalued and unappreciated in their jobs. To be successful in today's world, you need to be able to communicate effectively, have a strong mind, and be able to exercise your imagination and humour. If you do not have these skills, no amount of status or financial reward will compensate for your inadequacy as a human being.
To counter this problem, we need to rethink how work is defined and how it can be reconceived to suit us all. This means that we need to be able to design our own jobs, choose our own colleagues, and have more intimate conversations with our customers.
However, there are challenges to this. One challenge is that many employers are not willing to let their employees have too much autonomy. Another challenge is that traditional conversation skills are not always sufficient for the new kind of conversation that is needed in today's world.
Despite these challenges, I believe that we can all work towards a more fulfilling and meaningful work experience. By learning to communicate effectively, have a strong mind, and be able to exercise our imagination and humour, we can all create a more positive and equitable world.

Broadcasting is a technology that was originally designed to sow seeds broadly. It is also a metaphor for optimistic modernism. It is about planned growth and the production of a rich harvest. The metaphor presupposes a bucket of seeds at the centre of the activity, i.e. the existence of centralised resources intended and suited for spreading - and reproduction.
Since television is related to various two-way forms of communication, such as the telegraph and the telephone, it is all the more striking that, from its very early days, it was envisaged as a centralised 'mass' medium. However, transmission to private homes from some centralised unit was simply in keeping with both socio-economic structures and the dominant ways of life in modern and modernising societies.
The pervasiveness of these structured processes and interests rendered broadcasting the 'naturally' victorious organisation of both radio and television. What is left out here is the more positive view of broadcasting as a social form suitable also for democracy.

It's reasonable to have a basic need to create a home that meets your needs, but there's a point where the motivation for acquiring things gets out of control. Advertising plays on our insecurities. If you don't have one of these things, you're not as good as others. We are constantly being influenced by advertising messages. They are all designed to make you buy, buy, buy.
Caves are a small part of the natural environment that have been studied for many years. They arouse our curiosity and challenge our desire for knowledge. However, visiting caves requires physical agility, which means that cave research has been less in the hands of the learned professors than in most other scientific fields.
Meteorology is the study of weather. Countless people originally laid the foundations of meteorology using only their senses. Today, satellites and electronic instruments relay endless weather information to us. Computers can solve complex mathematical problems quickly. Meteorological theory is complex, but human experience is still the vital ingredient that translates computed data into weather forecasts. Human observations can still provide unusual evidence which is of great help to professionals who are trying to unravel the mysteries of the atmosphere.

Music and theatre are two different art forms that offer unique experiences to audiences. Opera, which is primarily a theatre performance, is often seen as the epitome of musical expression. However, after working at a national opera house, the author realized that music takes precedence over theatre in opera. The music comes first, followed by the actors and their performance. In contrast, theatre audiences have different expectations. They mainly understand the nature of an actor's skill and are not particularly impressed by long speeches. Despite these differences, there are similarities between the two art forms. For example, both audiences appreciate the skill of performers and are moved by the passion and emotion conveyed through music and acting. Additionally, both audiences contribute to the overall experience by applauding and expressing their appreciation.

However, when you step onto a beach towel, climb into a car, or walk across a recently vacuumed carpet, it pours off you. Sand can stay with you for a long time. It is a nuisance, but you can keep it away.

People prefer to use physical keys instead of computerised locking systems. One locksmith company developed a new electronic system that incorporated a proper metal key into the device.

In those days, the council houses in West Earlham stretched all over the city. They were row after row of huddled, dingy dwellings. In the summer, the chemicals from the May and Baker factory came and hung around the doors and gardens with an indescribable smell of sulphur. The most common sight in that part of Norwich early in the morning was a paperboy wrinkling his nose in disgust as he negotiated somebody's front path.
My early life has faded away, but I have a memory of sitting on a vantage point near an upstairs window and looking at the houses as they faded away into the distance. Later on, there are other phantoms - faces that I can't put names to, my mother ironing towels in the back room of a house that I don't think was ours, snow falling over the turrets of the great mansion at Earlham.
My mother was a solitary person. She was as alone in a room full of people as on a moor. She had a strong personality and was known for her strict rules and her obsession with cleanliness. To particularise, it meant not straying into neighbours' gardens or jeopardising their rose bushes as you walked down the street; it meant sitting for long half-hours in a silent dining room, with your hands folded across your chest, listening to radio programmes that your mother liked.
Growing up in West Earlham at this time followed a well-regulated pattern. Until you were five, you simply sat at home and got under your parents feet. Then, the September after your fifth birthday, you were packed off to Avenue Road infants school half a mile away in the direction of the city.

I headed down Philadelphia Avenue on the odd-numbered side. The dusk had deepened, and the humidity was high. I knew this side of the street from the dawn of consciousness. There were many houses down the street that I remembered. They had been as distinct to my childish awareness as the little troughs in the cement which led rain from their roof gutters out through the sidewalk to the street. As the street sloped downward, there was a just-perceptible descent in the social scale as well. The porches got lower to the ground, and the front yards became exiguous. Over the years, there had been changes. The wooden porch banisters and pillars had been replaced by wrought iron. The houses that had once been homes had become stores, and the stores that had once been homes had become stores again. How had the residents divided up those open, shelved spaces? How did they live with all those ghostly aromas of merchandise?
I swam in the pool one day. The warm rain tumbled from the gutter and turned into bubbles. The best moments were when the storm intensified. It was at the height of this drenching in the summer of 1996 that the notion of a long swim through Britain began to form itself. I wanted to follow the rain on its meanderings about our land to rejoin the sea, to break out of the frustration of a lifetime doing lengths, of endlessly turning back on myself like a tiger pacing its cage.

Charles Darwin thought that humans have a natural tendency to cry. He was probably wrong. Scientists have found that crying has a social significance. It can help to develop the attachment between mother and child. Tears can also be used to express sympathy, express helplessness, or be shed involuntarily. The sound of crying becomes less important than the visual signal it conveys. It may have been advantageous to early human communities as a means of promoting trust and social connectedness. However, the exact reasons why humans continue to cry into adulthood are still being investigated.

The Earth is getting warmer due to human activity. This is causing changes to the weather and the planet's climate. The changes are already having a significant impact on plants, animals, water and soils. Humans have learned to use natural resources to their advantage, but any changes to these resources have to be taken seriously.
The problem is that we do not fully understand the processes of the climatic system. However, most people agree that the rate of change will be faster than anything we have previously experienced. The effects of climate change are likely to be unfavourable in many areas, but there are also some potential benefits.
One of the most significant impacts of climate change is the rise in sea levels. This is caused by the thermal expansion of the ocean and the melting of ice. With so many people living in coastal zones, the consequences of rising sea levels are potentially very severe. Increased flooding and inundation are the most obvious results.
Another significant impact of climate change is the increased frequency of extreme weather events, such as heatwaves, floods and droughts. These events can have a devastating impact on ecosystems and human societies.

A couple is being selected to go on a 501-day trip to Mars. The applicants must be physically and emotionally strong. If the plans of a multi-millionaire named Dennis Tito are successful, this will be the first Martian astronaut mission. The spacecraft will travel about 160 kilometers above Mars. It will use the gravity of Mars to return to Earth without burning fuel. The goal is to be fuel-efficient. The next launch window when Mars and Earth align again is in 2031. There are plans to develop new technologies that could make the spacecraft successful. Even if the spacecraft never leaves Earth, the efforts to achieve these ambitious goals will not be in vain.

Aesthetics is a field that studies the theory of art. However, the existence of artworks often creates obstacles to understanding aesthetic theory. One reason is that artworks are physical products that exist outside of human experience. They are often identified with the building, book, painting, or statue in its existence apart from human experience. This creates conventions that get in the way of fresh insight.
Another reason is that the perfection of some artworks creates a sense of prestige and isolation. When artworks attain classic status, they become isolated from the human conditions under which they were brought into being and from the human consequences they engenders in actual life experience.
In order to understand the meaning of artistic products, we have to forget them for a time and have recourse to the ordinary forces and conditions of experience that we do not usually regard as aesthetic. We must arrive at the theory of art by means of a detour.
The arts which today have most vitality for the average person are things he or she does not take to be arts. For instance, the movies, jazz, comic strips, and, too frequently, lurid newspaper accounts of the week's events.

Lions are social animals that live in groups. They hunt for food together and work towards a common goal. However, lions are not always successful in their hunts. Sometimes, they are too generous and their companions benefit at their expense. Researchers have been studying lions for many years in an attempt to understand why they cooperate. But it has been difficult to uncover clues about their behaviour.

The early years of the 1990s were tough for advertising professionals. There was a recession in business that was longer, deeper and more severe than anticipated. It affected every single business in the country, including advertising agencies. Many people lost their jobs and homes, and the economy was in a bad state.
Despite the challenges, advertising professionals still feel pressure to do their jobs well. They are often asked to do more with less and are faced with increasing legal restrictions and the need to produce high-quality advertising.
The recession also had a negative impact on the advertising industry. It made it difficult for agencies to attract clients and made it harder to produce effective advertising. As a result, many advertising professionals feel frustrated and helpless.

The traveller is a person who has succumbed to the treacherous seduction of the unknown. They choose to put their lives at risk by climbing mountains, sailing the seas, or eating maggots. It is easy to dismiss such people as oddities. But they exist.
Sailing is a passion for me, but I am not a world-class sailor. I like to write about sailing. Sailing is guaranteed to provide alarms and achievements for my pen to celebrate. I have an electronic device that instantly gives me my position to within a few metres, anywhere on the earth's surface. I think the invention of the compass was a disaster. It has become the main object of the steersman's gaze, with the result that he no longer has to study the waves and feel the sea.

Summer promises us two great joys: escaping home and reading books. Books can help us to feel more at home in the world at large. We can relate our experiences to those described in great books written long ago or in distant lands. In the books of others, we find our own thoughts, embarrassments and dramas. Authors can locate words to depict a situation we thought ourselves alone in feeling, or can express our very own thoughts, but with a clarity and psychological accuracy we could not match.
Reading and travel can escape the deadening effect of habit. Our eyes are never more open than during our first few days in a new place. Our mind is like a radar newly attuned to pick up certain objects floating through consciousness. Our attention is drawn to the shades of the sky, to the changeability of a face, to the hypocrisy of a friend, or to a submerged sadness about a situation that we had previously not even known we could feel sad about.
There is no doubt the original motives behind the ecotourism movement were honourable attempts to provide a way for those who cared to make informed choices. But the lack of regulations and a standard industry definition left many travellers lost in an ecotourism jungle.

Music has had a significant impact on our lives in many ways. In the past, there has been a decline in the performance of live music and in the full-time employment opportunities for professional musicians. However, there has also been a widening access to music through technology. Music is often used in national events and individual activities. It provides opportunities for learning and playing instruments, as well as for enjoyment. There is evidence that playing an instrument can have positive effects on cognitive skills, social relationships, and concentration. As a result, there is likely to be a continuing demand for instrumental teaching in the short term. In the longer term, there are likely to be changes in the way music is listened to and performed. These changes will require a shift in focus for music education. In order to meet these changes, the music profession will need to adapt and evolve.

Actors often find themselves in situations where they are compelled to talk about their craft and themselves in interviews. Unfortunately, many actors fall into the trap of using ponderous cliches, silly truisms, or the prurient jaws of the gossip machine. To truly appreciate acting, one must pay attention to the execution rather than the discussion.
A review of Hamlet Adrian Lester's Hamlet is a testament to this principle. Lester's performance is characterized by its simplicity and assurance. His handling of the text and his physical and psychological self-control take him from brilliantly promising to frontline player.

Blogging: Confessing to the World
Some time ago, there was a website that talked about the risks of public check-ins. It said that if you post your location online, people you don't know can find out. This made people realize that there are some downsides to sharing everything on the internet.
The internet has opened up a lot of new opportunities to share our lives with the world. We can write blogs, post photos, and share our stories. But we need to be careful about what we share online. If we put too much information out there, it can have a negative impact on our lives.
One example of this is the story of Heather Armstrong, a young web worker in Los Angeles. She had a blog called Dooce and wrote about her job at a software company. One day, an anonymous colleague sent the address of Armstrong's blog to every vice president at her company. This resulted in her losing her job.
Another example is the story of Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student who began posting to the 'WWW' in 1994. He saw an opportunity to share his life and built a hypertext edifice of autobiography. But his story ended tragically when his home page was replaced with a video titled Dark Night.
These stories teach us that we need to be careful about what we share online. If we expect our song of ourselves to 'make people want to be with us', we'll be disappointed.

Tiredness has become a common condition in modern society. In the USA, research has found that 40 million Americans are chronically affected by sleeplessness. In Europe, there is a sleep research laboratory where they investigate the effects of fatigue on sailors, airpot noise on sleepers, and the dangers of motorway driving for flagging drivers.
Humans sleep according to a daily cycle. Once asleep, they switch between four different stages of unconsciousness. Dreams occur during the lightest sleep, and the brain paralyses the body except for the hands and eyelids.
There are some things that we know about human sleep with certainty. Women sleep for half an hour longer than men, and older people require less sleep. However, there are also a lot of theories about what sleep is for. Some people believe that sleep repairs body tissue, or restores muscles, or rests the frontal section of the brain that controls speech and creativity. But all of this may happen more quickly during relaxed wakefulness, so no one is really sure.

I was in Vienna to take photographs. Photographs were more than my livelihood. They were part of my life. The way light fell on a surface never failed to tug at my imagination. The way one picture, a single snapshot, could capture the essence of a time and place, a city, a human being, was embedded in my consciousness. One day, I might close the shutter on the perfect photograph. I was taking photographs and I was being paid to do it. It didn't sound bad to me.

Kinetic Art Rejoice is an exhibition that showcases the history of kinetic art in the twentieth century. Kinetic art is art that is concerned with movement. The exhibition includes paintings, drawings, documents, and films on kinetic art. Visitors are encouraged to make connections and discoveries for themselves.
The exhibition also features the work of David Hockney, a popular artist known for his figurative paintings and engaging personality. Some critics believe that Hockney is overrated, but he remains popular among many people. Hockney himself is aware of his limitations and does not claim to be a great artist.
The exhibition also includes a section on art history, discussing the importance of enjoying art and the relationship between art and society. It argues that knowledge and pleasure are not mutually exclusive.

Photography has been used to record all aspects of human life and activity for over a century. It has allowed human vision to be able to view the fleeting moment and to visualise both the vast and the minuscule. Photography has brought us images from remote areas of the world, distant parts of the solar system, as well as the social complexities and crises of modern life. It has also provided one of the most important and influential means of expressing the human condition.
The earliest creations of pictorial recording go as far back as the Upper Palaeolithic period of about 35,000 years ago. Pictures seem to be inextricably linked to human culture as we understand it. Throughout the history of visual representation, questions have been raised concerning the supposed accuracy (or otherwise) of the visual image, as well as its status in society.
Photography is regarded quite naturally as offering such convincing forms of pictorial evidence that this process of communication often seems to render the medium totally transparent, blurring the distinction between our perception of the environment and its photographic representations.
I hope to show that the camera is not merely a mute, passive chronicler of events, and that photography does not just passively reflect culture, but can provide the vision and impetus that promote social and political change and development.

To write poetry, you need to read a lot, write a lot, and use your imagination and creativity. You can also write to a schedule or wait for inspiration to strike. The most important thing is to find your own rhythm and let your creativity flow.

Writing is a human instinct, but written language is not. It is a complex skill that takes time and practice to learn. Children are naturally wired for sound, but they need to learn how to read and write. We need to understand how the minds of children work and how to help them learn to write.

I have never begun a novel with more uncertainty. If I call it a novel, it is because I don't know what else to call it. I have little story to tell and I end neither with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader in the air. This book consists of my recollections of a man with whom I was thrown into close contact only at long intervals. I have little knowledge of what happened to him in between. I only want to set down what I know. To save embarrassment to people still living, I have given to the persons who play a part in this story names of my own contriving. I have taken pains to make sure that no one should recognise them. The man I am writing about is not famous. It may be that he never will be. It may be that when his life at last comes to an end he will leave no more trace of his sojourn on earth than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the surface of the water. Then my book, if it is read at all, will be read only for what intrinsic interest it may possess. Poetry recitals are a popular way to enjoy poetry. There are two main types of poetry recitals: those that are intended to be printed and read on the page, and those that are intended to be performed live. The poets who write for the page tend to write more complex and nuanced poems than the poets who write for performance. However, the poems that are written for performance are often simpler in form and content, and can be more easily assimilated at a single hearing. Attending poetry recitals can be a valuable guide as to where the precise emphases are to be placed, but it is desirable that the audience should either follow the reading with the text before them or have a prior knowledge of the poems being spoken.

Oral History
The use of oral evidence in history has its challenges. It is not always accurate or complete. The historian's role is to select informants and indicate the area of interest. The presence of an outsider can affect the atmosphere in which the informant recalls the past. Historians must accept responsibility for their share in creating new evidence.
Animal Science
There are two main approaches to animal science - the physiological and the whole animal. Physiologists study the body's mechanisms and behaviour. Ethologists study the naturally occurring behaviour of animals. Although there is some overlap, the two approaches are distinct.
The Social Sciences
Studying a social science for the first time can be challenging. You must learn the substance and methodology of the subject simultaneously. Each social science discipline focuses on a particular aspect of social life and uses its own set of concepts.
Classical Architecture
Classical architecture is more than just the construction of buildings. It is an art form that emphasizes aesthetics and proportion. The origins of classical architecture are complex. However, the basic principles of form and proportion remain the same throughout history.

I claimed that I had found a secret tunnel and crawled and swum along it until I got out. My father was not convinced. He said that the whole well was dangerous. I felt ashamed and worried about my future moral standing.

Ralph unlocked the door to his flat and entered the dark hall. He felt a sense of ownership and security in his flat. It was a place where he could focus and be alone. He had grown impatient with its inability to be transformed. There was a small puddle of letters and a red eye of the answering machine that sometimes gathered by the door. He was grateful that the glassy eyes of his windows hadn't been smashed. From the dreary distance of his office, Ralph often looked forward to his solitary evenings at home. He would read or listen to music as the night deepened outside. He felt powerless and unable to find his purpose in life. He had tried to formulate a plan for his own betterment, but he had been unsuccessful. He had attended his only interview and was offered a job. I was at Easter Monday in Buccoo Village to witness goat racing. There were a lot of people and food stalls at the event. I had to fight my way through the crowds to get a good spot. A course was set up for the competitors. It wasn't as impressive as established racecourses, but it was similar to the idea that spectators would line both sides of a stretch of ground. The goats were being kept in order. They are very strong animals that can eat almost anything.
As the day came to an end, I started to think about the night ahead. There was no place to stop or sleep, and we hadn't seen any villages or huts since early morning. It was dark and we couldn't see much. We put in new batteries for our torch, but they didn't work. We couldn't find a place to camp. After a while, we saw a flickering light and hoped it was a sign. It turned out to be moonlight glinting on waves. We couldn't see what was happening, but we heard the sound of fast-rushing water. Time stood still and we moved on.

There are some activities that take a long time to complete. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient and add the oil too quickly, the mayonnaise curdles. If you start tugging with frustration on a tangled fishing line, the knot just becomes tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some of its functions are performed at lightning speeds; others take seconds, minutes, hours, days or even years to complete their course. Some can be speeded up - we can become quicker at solving crossword puzzles or doing mental arithmetic. But others cannot be rushed, and if they are, then they will break down, like the mayonnaise, or get tangled up, like the fishing line.
The mind possesses three different processing speeds. The first is faster than thought. The second is thought itself: the sort of intelligence which does involve figuring matters out, weighing up the pros and cons, constructing arguments and solving problems. The third is slower and more purposeful, more playful, leisurely or dreamy.
This leisurely, apparently aimless, way of knowing and experiencing is just as intelligent as the other faster ones. Allowing the mind time to meander is not a luxury that can safely be cut back as life or work gets more demanding. On the contrary, thinking slowly is a vital part al the cognitive armoury.

Amateur Astronomy
Many things have changed in astronomy over the past half-century. There were few charts and catalogues and telescopic equipment was limited. Today, there is a wide range of telescopes and equipment available. Computers have revolutionised almanacs and chart production. All this makes this the golden age of amateur astronomy.
However, there has also been a loss of simplicity. Now one may have to travel a long distance to find a sky comparable to that found in urban areas 50 years ago. The daytime skies are now plagued by aircraft condensation trails which can persist for hours and often spread out to form amorphous clouds, making solar observations impossible and hampering night-time observation too.
McAndrews Hotel
Every summer we spend a fortnight in McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition that has achieved a certain sacredness. Nothing is allowed to interfere with the ritual. We are of a kind, McAndrews clientele: old-fashioned, odd perhaps, some would say snobbish. I do not like the bad manners, the insolence of shop assistants which passes for egalitarianism in this present age; I resent chummy overtures from waiters who sometimes appear to restrain themselves with difficulty from slapping one on the back. I know most of my fellow-guests' names - like me they have been coming here since they were children - yet can rest assured that when I meet any of them in any part of the hotel, I shall be spared all social intercourse apart from a civil word of greeting. Scientists There was an interesting thing on the radio last week. It seems that a bunch of scientists are getting themselves hot under the collar over what drives them to be scientists. Surely, it's more important to know whether what we scientists are doing is right, rather than get bogged down in debates over the point of it all. I would have thought that the crucial issue here is not why we pursue it, but to recognise that science is a tool, and we are the ones who should decide how, where, when and why to use it.

Maps are used to show the relationships of points and features on the Earth's surface. They are determined by distance and direction. In the past, distance was often measured in units of time, but such measurements gave more information about the relative ease of crossing the local terrains than about actual distance. Direction is also an important element of maps. The accurate representation of direction was not of primary importance for ordinary travellers. Written itineraries for a long time rivalled maps. Today, certain types of maps, such as those showing railway systems, may make little attempt to show true directions. Landmarks along a route were at first indicated by signs. The conventions employed in maps varied with the purpose of the map and from place to place. In order to address the demands of different users, the present-day cartographer has had to evolve methods of mapping all kinds of 'distributions'.

The students are all there to have fun, and the tutor does not want to paint petals on teacups with the robotic rapidity I had remembered.

The Wrong Country Uncle chose a package holiday for them at a very reasonable price. When Keith and Dawne went to make the booking, the counter clerk explained that the other members of that particular package were a school group from the south coast, all of them learning Italian. But something went wrong. They ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, somewhere in Switzerland.
They were offered beds in the hotel, but they became alarmed when they realized that they were being offered them for the duration of their holiday. They contacted the receptionist and informed him of the mistake. The receptionist did not know about the mistake. But the travel agency was able to help them. They were put on a coach and taken to the correct hotel.
They spent the rest of their holiday enjoying the lakeside air and the water birds. They were tired but happy. They didn't say to one another that there was an irony in the catastrophe that had occurred.

Ernest Shackleton was an American executive who was adopted as a model of good management. Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a rough idea of what he did. America has only just discovered him. Now the Americans are making up for lost time with powerful enthusiasm. They are producing biographies and accounts of Shackleton's voyage, mounting a grand exhibition, and preparing a film based on his life. Some American managers have also adopted Shackleton as an icon and exemplar. His qualities as a leader and communicator are being used to teach others.
Shackleton was known for his determination, resourcefulness, and ability to lead others. He was also known for his ability to communicate clearly and effectively. He believed that an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance, and patience. He led by example and showed others that anything can be accomplished with hard work and determination.

In the forests of Madagascar, there lives a primate named the aye-aye. The aye-aye is similar to a woodpecker. It bores through wood and probes cavities beneath the surface in its search for insect larvae. The aye-aye uses its incisor teeth to gnaw its way in and its narrow, elongated third finger to probe and scoop. Scientists have discovered that the aye-aye can locate the insects hidden inside the wood by tapping the surface of the wood with its middle finger and listening for reverberations. The theory that the aye-aye takes the place of woodpeckers in the woodpecker-free forests of Madagascar is an attractive one.

Most of us have photographs of our grandparents, but how many of us know what their lives were like. We often intend to write things down, but never get round to it. We may leave videos rather than photographs, but the images will remain two-dimensional. Hannah Renier has come up with an answer: she writes other people's autobiographies. The idea came to her when she talked to members of her family and realised how much of the past that was part of her own life was disappearing.
Each book involves up to 30 hours of taped interviews which Ms Renier uses as the basis to write the life story. The final content is as good as its subject. The hook that emerges does not look like a cheap product - and carries a price tag of nearly PS3,000, with extra copies at PS25 each.

The University Museum of Classical Archaeology houses a collection of casts of Greek and Roman sculpture. The sculptures are replicas cast from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The museum is housed in a purpose-built gallery with excellent natural light. The advantages of plaster casts are many, including the ability to bring together sculptures that were originally split up. Nearly all the most celebrated works of Greek and Roman sculpture can be viewed in one afternoon.
The Sedgwick Museum of Geology houses a magnificent collection of fossil animals, plants, rocks and minerals. The museum also houses Britain's oldest intact geological collection. The collection is arranged by geological age so that the major changes in life on Earth can be traced through time.
The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs contains a large collection of air photographs. The photographs are of considerable general interest as a detailed, year-by-year record of the landscape.
The Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre offers a unique opportunity to create wall hangings by rubbing brass plates off tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The brass plates are replicas of originals and are spread across medieval Europe.

From here to paternity, I have been blessed with 35 years of small children. I have loved every minute of it. I had the pleasure of feeding the baby this morning and that for me is what being a father is all about. I'm terribly lucky with my children. We all love the same things: opera, theatre, books, music. It creates a great bond.
I have been guilty of slapping my children in anger, but I don't condone it. I'm sure I have not been a deeply attentive father but I have always tried to be available. I'm here if they need me, always on the basis that they ring me.
I have never felt out of touch. Because I was struggling to establish the business when they were young there were things I missed: first concerts, sports days. I'm sad about that, but there are compensations now, like being able to take them on holidays to the south of France.
I think it has been an advantage that I do something they see as glamorous and interesting. I've noticed more and more MPs bringing their kids to the House. Maybe we are all becoming more conscious of the need to involve our children in our lives.

Marlowe's epic play, Tamburlaine the Great, is a thrilling night of the year at the Swan Theatre in Stratford-upon-Avon. Terry Hands' production combines the glories of Marlowe's play with speed and physicality. Antony Sher is in terrific form in the title role, delivering a speech that demands the audience's complete attention.
The play "Women Laughing Welcome" is a powerful and compassionate study of the devastating effects of illness. It is seen at the Royal Court Theatre in London.
Billy Roche's latest play, "Amphibians," explores the decline of the fishing industry. It is seen at the Barbican 3 Pit Theatre in London.
The play "Murder by Misadventure" is a traditional thriller involving a crime-writing partnership intent on killing each other. It is seen at the Whitehall Theatre in London.
The Alchemist is a comedy of 17th-century confidence tricksters. It is seen at the Barbican Theatre in London.
The Madras House is a panoramic comedy about fashion and the position of women in Edwardian society. It is seen at the Lyric Theatre in Hammersmith, London.
Dreams from a Summer House is a delightful new musical. It is seen at the Stephen Joseph Theatre in Scarborough.
The Merry Wives of Windsor is a farcical comedy. It is seen at the Shakespeare Theatre in Stratford-upon-Avon.
The Voysey Inheritance is a major Granville Barker revival. It is touring the regions.

Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game when they find out that one of their customers is her Uncle Jim. He tries to manipulate her affection for him and alienate her from her friends. When Emma finds her life in danger, things take a dark and compelling turn.
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, join forces to investigate a train accident that happened in 1915. Varied viewpoints and documents help the reader understand what happened and why.
Mary Dyer doesn't fit into her family or male-dominated culture. She loves her father's racing pigeons and knows enough to carry on managing the loft and winning prizes.
Robert Westall uses the viewpoint of a mature woman for this chilling story of rural prejudice and persecution. Rose feels just as dismayed by the methodical ruthlessness of her teenage son.
Someone's Mother is Missing is a story about two teenagers, Sam and Lisa, who gain a better sense of reality and the value of family through their developing closeness.
Stanley's Aquarium is a story about a young woman who takes care of elderly Stanley and finds him fascinating and later repellent.

Science flying in the face of gravity. Journalist Tom Mumford joined students using weightlessness to test their theories. It looked like just another aircraft from the outside. The pilot told his young passengers that it was built in 1964, a Boeing KC-135 refuelling tanker, based on the Boeing 707 passenger craft. The aircraft took off smoothly enough, but any lingering illusions the young scientists and I had that we were on anything like a scheduled passenger service were quickly dispelled when the pilot put the Boeing into a 45-degree climb which lasted around 20 seconds. The engines strained wildly, blood drained from our heads, and bodies were scattered across the cabin floor. After that, the engines cut out and the transition to weightlessness was nearly instantaneous. We floated aimlessly; the idea of going anywhere was itself confusing. Left or right, up or down, no longer had any meaning. Only gravity, by rooting us somewhere, permits us to appreciate the possibility of going somewhere else. After ten seconds of freefall descent, the pilot pulled the aircraft out of its nose dive. The return of gravity was less immediate than its loss, but was still sudden enough to ensure that some of the students came down with a bump.

I planted my stake in New Zealand. I had a peculiar period of my life when I didn't have any summers. I went out to New Zealand every summer here, which is the New Zealand winter, and so I had nine winters on the trot. I like winter. My parents came up with this idea of buying a small plot of land which 'the kids', my brother, sister and I, could look after. We planted the whole 70 acres between the three of us. It rained a lot that year. I enjoy hard physical work. The rhythm is something that everybody tells you about and, of course, it's true of many agricultural jobs that you actually have to train the body into a series of quite standardised moves, and then it becomes immensely easy. The connection between me and that area is still immensely strong.

Six years ago, I turned my dairy farm in Somerset into an 'open farm' and have established a reputation for looking after orphaned animals. One day, I found three small grey badger cubs. Their coats were like velvet, and milky-coloured eyes looked up at me from three tiny black-and-white striped heads. I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and installed them beside the stove for warmth.
The cubs were fed every four hours and progressed to drinking from a bottle and moving around, albeit shakily. After a few weeks, they were weaned on to creamed rice and other foods. As they grew older, they began to turn nocturnal and would go for walks only at dusk or late at night.
I have a lot of fun walking with the badgers. We often go through the cider orchard and chase each other's tails. It is a very exciting sport. We also have a sett on the farm where the badgers live. It is a big place with tunnels and chambers. The badgers are very happy in their new home.

Sir Edmund Halley was a renowned astronomer and geophysicist who made significant contributions to the field of navigation. He is best known for his discovery of the comet that bears his name. One of his greatest accomplishments was charting the variations of the compass, which are now known as declination. Without declination, sailors were unable to correct their compasses and navigate accurately.
Halley's journey to chart declination took him to various locations, including Cape Verde Islands, Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and England. From these travels, he published a chart that proved indispensable to seamen for more than a century.
Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, is planning to commemorate the three-hundredth anniversary of Halley's trip by retracing his route. The projected expedition, which he has entitled 'In the Wake of the Paramore,' will involve making precise measurements of declination using advanced instruments. The data collected should help refine the existing mathematical model of Earth's magnetic field.
Does Dr. Clark possess the credentials to make his parallel voyage a success? He has extensive experience in navigation and has already sailed the distance from Rio de Janeiro to England. He envisages that the expedition will be completed in four stages, with four different crews. And does he share Halley's obsessive trait? Dr. Clark is prepared to dedicate himself fully to the expedition, but he emphasizes that he would not sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason.

Peacocks that live at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire, UK, show off their magnificent trains to the hens. The peacocks' trains are very impressive, but they are not necessarily advantageous. Darwin argued that living creatures came to be the way they are by evolution, rather than by special creation. He believed that the fittest individuals are most likely to survive and reproduce. However, the peacocks' tail is not necessarily an indicator of fitness. Wallace suggested that the train was not an end in itself, but an advertisement for some genuine contribution to survival. Now, researchers are trying to settle the matter once and for all. They are studying the peacocks' behavior and offspring to see if there is a relationship between the size of the tail and fitness. If there is, then Darwin's theory of sexual selection would be vindicated.

The best boat design combines old and new. Tom Cunliffe says that. He designed his own craft, 'The Westerman', this week. The boat show in London has many fine yachts with new technology. They are all descendants of the hull-shape revolution that took place 25 years ago. My boat is different. It is designed on a tidal creek off the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it could be 100 years old. It has all the benefits of a glass fibre boat yet looks like, feels like and sails like the real thing.

Health farms and country house hotels offering spa facilities are popular among stressed working women. Many of these places provide a variety of treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, pedicures, and facials. The atmosphere at these places is typically calm and relaxing.
If you are feeling stressed and need a break, a health farm or country house hotel offering spa facilities may be the perfect place for you. There are many different health farms and country house hotels to choose from, so you can find one that meets your needs and budget.
Some of the most popular treatments at health farms and country house hotels include aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, pedicures, and facials. Aromatherapy is a relaxing treatment that uses essential oils to promote well-being. Seaweed baths are a detoxifying treatment that can help you lose weight and improve your skin. Manicures and pedicures are a great way to relax and pamper yourself. Facials are a rejuvenating treatment that can help you look and feel your best.

In the past few million years, humans have not developed any significant differences from chimpanzees. We are still more than 98% identical to chimps genetically. Our physical capacity for making art and anything else we consider uniquely human must be due to a small number of genes. Modern studies of animal behaviour have shown that many similarities between humans and animals exist. For example, tools are used not only by humans but also by wild chimpanzees and sea otters. As for language, monkeys have a simple one, with separate warning sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle' and 'snake'. These discoveries leave us with few absolute differences, other than art, between ourselves and animals.
If human art sprang from a unique genetic endowment, it's strange that our ancestors dispensed with it for at least the first 6.9 million of the 7 million years since they diverged from chimps. The earliest art forms may well have been wood carvings or body painting. But if they were, we wouldn't know it, because those materials don't get preserved. Not until the Cro-Magnons, beginning around 35,000 years ago, do we have unequivocal evidence for a distinctly human art.
There are three supposed distinctions between human art and animal activities. First, human art is non-utilitarian, it's made for aesthetic pleasure and it's transmitted by learning rather than by genes. Second, human art is not motivated by aesthetic pleasure. Third, human art is a learned rather than an instinctive activity. However, these distinctions are not entirely clear. Like human paintings, the ape paintings served no narrow utilitarian functions. They were produced not for material regard but only for the painter's satisfaction.

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on earth. It is also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell the tale.
There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to specialize in them. These days you no longer find such people in fiction, let alone in real life.
Blackmore's great adventure consisted of leading an expedition across the Taklamakan Desert. The team was composed of four Britons, an American photographer, four Chinese, 30 camels and six camel handlers.
The team suffered unspeakable hardships, but they managed to find water and survive. They walked for 1,000 kilometres and were very thin and muscular despite their physical exhaustion.
Blackmore went on to describe lying in the desert gazing up at a full moon, thinking of his family. He felt prouder of that expedition than of anything else he'd done.

Life was getting out of hand. Susan Harr decided to unplug her gadgets and rediscover the joys of manual labour. Everyone loves technology. It makes life easier and leaves us with more time to do other things. However, a recent experience with her malfunctioning word processor has confirmed a suspicion that gadgets are often not worth the expense or the trouble. Are we as dependent on technology as we imagine? Bit by bit, I have been letting the household technology fall by the wayside as its natural and often short life expires. I am not tied to a noisy, whirring machine, and I can take my time over the garment. I can sew and listen to the radio, or I can talk with family and friends. There is a wonderfully soothing quality about executing a craft by hand, a great satisfaction in watching one's work become neater, more assured.

The cabinet-maker Charles Hurst makes furniture. He is busy and has a lot of work. He has built up a good reputation for himself and his order book is always full. People like his furniture because it is well-crafted and made with simple lines.
Hurst is self-taught and has a natural ability for making things. He has been making furniture for ten years and has a lot of experience. He is also gracious in his praise for others.
However, Hurst is also critical of some contemporary furniture-makers. He believes that some people are trying to be artists and take too long to make one piece. He also has little time for degree shows, in which students exhibit their work but at the same time are 'trying to make fashion statements.
Despite his self-deprecating mood, Hurst is proud of his work and is always willing to help others. He is a skilled craftsman who takes pride in his craft and is always willing to share his knowledge.

People spend a significant portion of their lives asleep. Sleep plays an important role in maintaining physical health and cognitive abilities. There are three main theories about the purpose of sleep. The most common theory proposes that sleep is primarily physiological, serving to repair damage and restore the body to its optimal functioning state. A second theory emphasizes the learning benefits of sleep, suggesting that it allows us to process and consolidate information acquired during the day. The third theory focuses on the energy-related benefits of sleep, arguing that it is essential for recharging our energy reserves and maintaining optimal energy levels for the following day.

Someone who behaves abnormally or refuses to conform to the accepted norms of society is called eccentric. Eccentricity is the assertion of our individuality. It is as though in the depths of our psyche we have two locomotives head-to-head on the same track, pushing against each other. One is called individualism and the other conformity. Most of us have our own unique quirks and oddities. It is the desire to be accepted and loved that is stronger than the desire to stand out in the crowd. If you have unusual hobbies, strong opinions, or unconventional behaviour, you may find that you attract other people who share your interests. You can form clubs, hold meetings, and organise rallies where you can get together and discuss your common enthusiasms or problems.

Natural books have influenced many people. Some of the most influential books include Only One Earth, Progress for a Small Planet, The Home of Man, Signals for Survival, and My Family and Other Animals.
The Home of Man is a book about the explosive growth of the world's cities. It is a compelling book that has been praised for its eloquent and impassioned plea for sustainable human development.
Signals for Survival is a book about animal communication. It explains superbly through words and pictures the fascinating world of animal communication.
My Family and Other Animals is a book about the author's devotion to the natural world. It is an extraordinary book that has had a lasting impact on the author's life.
The Shell Bird Book is a book about ornithological information and the appreciation of birds. It is a comprehensive book that includes chapters on migrants and migration, a review of the history of birds in Britain, and a chapter on birds in music, literature and art.

DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS? We asked five leading British publishers about the effect of book reviews on their commercial success. They said that reviews are very important for publishers. However, publishers also said that reviews are not the only factor that affects sales. They said that other factors such as word-of-mouth recommendations and marketing can also help to sell books.

The craft of making weathervanes is an ancient skill that has been practiced for centuries. Today, the craft is still very much alive in the workshop that Graham Smith has set up. He is one of the few people in the country who make hand-cut weathervanes. Graham's designs are individually created and tailored to the specific requirements of his customers.
Graham decided to concentrate his efforts on a weathervane business. He had worked as a precision engineer and had sewn an apprenticeship in that trade. He had a lot of experience in engineering, but he wanted to do something that was more creative and artistic. He started making weathervanes and people loved his unique designs.
Graham has perfected over 100 original designs. He works to very fine detail, always seeking approval for the design of the silhouette from the customer before proceeding with the hand-cutting. He also keeps plenty of traditional designs in stock, since they prove as popular as the one-offs.
Graham has become increasingly busy, supplying flat-packed weathervanes to clients worldwide. American and Danish buyers in particular are showing interest. 'Pricing,' he explains, 'depends on the intricacy of the design.'

The Horse Whisperer was a popular book that was published in the year it was released. It was written by a British screenwriter named Nicholas Evans. The book earned Evans a lot of money.
The first months of the year were not kind to Evans. He was disappointed when his film project, Life and Limb, fell through. He was also struggling financially. He had not earned any money in two years and was in debt.
Evans decided to write his first novel, The Horse Whisperer, instead of going back to his old job or starting a new project. He spent a lot of time researching the subject and writing the book.
The book was eventually sold to a publisher for a record-breaking sum. Evans was grateful for his success and was excited to write his next novel.

Young Masters Age is against Bobby Fischer as he seeks to re-establish himself in the game of chess. Chess is more than ever a young man's game. After 20 years of self-imposed exile, Mr Bobby Fischer has returned to chess and is playing his old adversary Boris Spassky. Mr Fischer's victory in the first game was a masterpiece, simple but profound. However, as subsequent games have shown, this balding, bearded chess player is not the man of 1972. He is 49 years old, out of practice and out of shape. The game of chess has also changed a lot over the past two decades. The new era of professionalism was born out of Mr Fischer's own popularisation of the game. The rise of the professional chess circuit has seen the competitive aspect of the game overtake the scientific and artistic. The sole aim of the modern master is to win. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are as crucial as his intellect and wisdom. The pressure of the game has always been intense, but now the playing sessions themselves are becoming longer, and many games are played without a break. The increased pressure has swung the pendulum in youth's favour. Over the past 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than his predecessor. The game of chess is physically and mentally taxing. A single game may last up to eight hours. For the chess master this period represents a ceaseless struggle. A lapse in concentration can mean disaster. So the adversaries are always in a state of nervous tension. The presence of the chess clock adds to the tension. The climax of the game is often a furious 'time scramble'. With minds racing and hands twitching, the masters blitz out their moves and press their clocks with a co-ordination that any athlete would admire.

Fame and fortune are two things that many people dream of, and the stories of the new British talent showcased in this article are no exception. From poet to pop star, these young individuals are making their mark on the world.
Nick Grosso, a playwright in his early 30s, has written three critically acclaimed plays and is currently adapting his first play, Peaches, into a screenplay. He believes that writing for actors is more important than reading, and he has a passion for his craft that is evident in his work.
Simon Pegg, a comedian, has come a long way since studying drama at Bristol University. He is currently writing a television comedy series and has just finished a punishing tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He believes that comedy is not the hardest job in the world and that anyone with courage and good material can make people laugh.
Ciaran McMenamin, a young actor, has gained widespread recognition for his role in the series The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star. He is grateful for the opportunity to pick and choose his work and is excited about his future prospects.
Neil Taylor, a lead singer in the pop band Matrix, has achieved success through hard work and determination. He has been trying to break into the music business for years and is thrilled to have signed a deal with Domino Records.
Stephen Richards, a poet and author, has won numerous awards and is known for his captivating poetry readings. He is also excited about his upcoming novel, Hidden, and believes that writing a novel is a more challenging and rewarding experience than writing poetry.

In a novel, 'Our Hero Feels Inspired', the author writes with terrific verve and creates a captivating story. The novel is divided into five chapters, each with a unique theme.
The first chapter introduces the protagonist, Isabel, an art student who seeks Mr Right but is concerned about her knobbly knees. The second chapter describes the local radio station, WLT Radio, and its quirky employees. The third chapter explores the relationship between a second husband and his wive's first husband. The fourth chapter introduces two sets of best friends and their intertwined lives. The fifth chapter tells the story of a man who becomes 'father' to his brother's orphaned children.
The author's writing is characterized by his use of vivid imagery and his ability to create engaging characters. The novel is a pleasure to read and will appeal to a wide audience.

Volunteer tourism is a topic that four academic writers discuss. It can have both positive and negative impacts. On the one hand, volunteering can lead to greater international understanding, enhanced ability to solve conflicts, and growth of international social networks among ordinary people. It can also play a role in developing people who will, in the course of their careers and lives, act ethically in favour of those less well-off. On the other hand, volunteer tourism can be imperialist, paternalistic charity, or a self-serving quest for career and personal development on the part of well-off Westerners. It can also bypass the democratic imperative of representative government and reduce development to individual acts of charity.

Many people listen to the radio when they wake up in the morning. To wake up, most people need some external means. One common way to wake up is the clock radio. But how do you pick a good one? Our panel, which consisted of myself, Tom Granger, and Paul Bridges, tested five currently available clock radios.
We all thought the quality of the radios was excellent, but we found that the biggest one was too big for our bedside tables. The biggest radio was as big as a rugby ball. We also found that the radios were difficult to set up. However, we all agreed that the radios worked well once they were set up.
The simplest and cheapest of all the models tested, this one scored points with Tom Granger because it 'seemed very standard and took up little space'. However, he also accepted that manufacturers had been obliged to improve the quality of radios because of the advent of button-tuning.

A hedgehog is a small mammal that has sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many different parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. Hedgehogs have the ability to roll into a tight ball when they are attacked. The effectiveness of this defence mechanism depends on the number of spines the hedgehog has. Some desert hedgehogs have evolved to carry out weight, and consequently, they have fewer spines and are more likely to attempt to run into their attacker, using their ball rolling ability as a last resort. Hedgehogs are primarily nocturnal and sleep for much of the day, either under cover of bushes or in a hole in the ground. Despite the fact that all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all choose to do so; in suitable conditions, some will stay awake all year round.

To excel in any sport is challenging, even for men. Women have to be even tougher. Training and competition leave little time for a normal life, so sacrifices must be made. Despite the odds, women are breaking records and overcoming prejudice.
Here, we talk to just a few brilliant British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.
A. Jill, a skier, says, "It's a great feeling to fly through the air and land cleanly, but it can be scary. You just get on with it. It's not easy to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months of the year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends. But it was my choice."
B. Caroline, a cyclist, says, "I'm well paid as a pro, and cycling has lots of potential in terms of endorsements. However, I know I'm not ugly and it worries me that people may think I've got where I'm at because of how I look, not because I'm the best cyclist. So I tend to concentrate on the cycling at the moment, rather than earning money."
C. Annabel, a rower, says, "Rowing is hard for girls to get into because very few girls' schools do it. So most don't start till they're 19 or 20 which makes it harder to succeed at an international level."
D. Ffyona, a long-distance walker, says, "I was doing 50 miles and 21 hours each day with three hours sleep in high temperatures and walking with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record!"
E. Lisa, a saloon car racer, says, "Being a woman has its disadvantages. When I get to a corner, the men think 'I've got to beat her', so I've had a lot of knocks!"
F. Alison, a triathlete, says, "I get up at 5.30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on my sleep. In the evening I just cycle or run. Yes, I do fall asleep at my desk sometimes!"

The day I met Picasso, I was an 18-year-old student travelling around Europe and Morocco. I found a boat-painting job on the waterfront and spent much of my time drawing. One day, I met Picasso at a restaurant in Cannes harbour. He was seated with his wife and three companions. I was surprised to see him and managed to get his signature. Picasso was known to be a reclusive artist, so I was doubly astonished to find him in such a public place. I drew a portrait of Picasso and he gave me a generous nod. He also signed my drawing. I was delighted to meet Picasso and I feel grateful for the opportunity to have been able to draw his portrait.

Talking shop Ever entered a store and bought more than you intended to buy? Supermarkets know that shoppers place a premium on fresh produce being in stores. They often display fresh fruit and veg at the entrance of a store, or even a display of house plants for sale. They may also provide an in-store bakery that wafts irresistible fresh bread smells around a large area of the store.
Supermarkets also use lighting to attract shoppers. With chainstores, the aim is to achieve lighting which is as close to natural light as possible. With supermarkets, special lighting (and mirrors) may be used to enhance certain foods, particularly fresh fruit and veg.
Many chainstores have divided up their floors with different carpeting - one pattern for the routes through a store and one defining sales areas. Shoppers are drawn naturally along these routes known within the trade as the 'Yellow Brick Road'.
As you enter a supermarket, giant colour photographs of succulent roasts, fancy cakes and cheeses hit you - irresistible if you've had nothing to eat before setting out on your shopping trip.
