Sea, Ice & Rock Mountaineer Chris Bonnington and Robin Knox-Johnston are known for their achievements in climbing and sailing. Bonnington has climbed the summit of Everest and pioneered routes in Britain and the Alps. Knox-Johnston was the first to circumnavigate the world single-handedly. The two teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland. They wrote a book about their trip called Sea, Ice and Rock.
One day, the author was working on a book about adventure and called Knox-Johnston to ask for an interview. They went sailing and climbing together in Greenland. The author found that Knox-Johnston was a natural sailor and that he enjoyed tinkering with the engine or mending the lavatory.
The author also found that climbing together was difficult. He had to watch for Robin's safety and make sure that he was safe. The author felt that he was useless at times and that he was concerned about the boat. However, he also knew that Knox-Johnston was worried about the boat and that he was all in favour of having another go at climbing the mountain.

Apples have been with humans since the dawn of recorded time. They have been eaten in many different ways throughout history. In ancient times, apples were used for food, medicine, and religious ceremonies. Today, apples are grown all over the world and are one of the most popular fruits.
Apples are grown commercially from just a few varieties. Most apples are grown for their red skin or because they travel well rather than because they taste good. This is a problem because it can lead to a lack of variety in apples.
Consumers are starting to demand more variety in apples. We can all help to save diversity in apples by buying a variety of apples from the store. We can also plant apple trees in our own gardens. By working together, we can ensure that apples continue to be enjoyed for many years to come.

Explore Worldwide offers a variety of adventure travel experiences designed for people who want to get more out of their holiday than just a beach. The company specializes in travel to new and unusual destinations, coupled with interesting and original itineraries. Explore Worldwide has a brochure containing over 100 original adventures in more than 60 countries around the world. Most trips last from 1-4 weeks and are led by small informal groups of 16 people.
The company offers a wide range of activities, including hiking, safaris, and river journeys. They also provide opportunities to meet ethnic peoples and explore remote wilderness areas. Explore Worldwide emphasizes sustainability and responsible travel practices. The company believes that travel can be a powerful force for understanding and tolerance between different races and peoples.
Explore Worldwide is perfect for travelers who want to experience the world in a unique and memorable way. Whether you are interested in exploring remote wilderness areas, meeting ethnic peoples, or simply enjoying the beauty of nature, Explore Worldwide has an adventure for you.

**
The long-distance runner Richard Nerurkar, one of Britain's top 10,000-meter runners, visited a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. The camp is located ten miles south of the equator and is surrounded by beautiful playing fields and dense tropical vegetation. The athletes live in cinder-block dormitories and train hard, running up to 40 kilometers each day.
The training camp is basic, but the athletes have everything they need to train and live comfortably. They eat simple meals, such as tea, bread, and boiled eggs, and they have access to clean water and streams for bathing.
By the time Nerurkar left the camp, he was even more appreciative of Kenyan success. He couldn't stop himself pondering upon a rather different explanation for the success of Kenyan runners: the purity and simplicity of the mountainside lifestyle, the gruelling work-outs, and their passion for success.

**
Advertising is not doing well. It started to plummet early in 1989, well before the recession really began to bite. The main problem with advertising is that it has failed to keep up with the pace of economic change. Advertising is not effective because it is not targeted. Most people do not buy most of the brands they see advertised. Waste is inherent in the use of media for advertising. However, advertising can be cost-effective. If an advertiser can target the right audience, they can be successful.

Solar Survivor Charles Clover ventures inside Britain's most environmentally-friendly home, Southwell in Nottinghamshire. The house is designed and built by Robert and Brenda Vale. They use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into garden compost and heat their house with waste heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat. The house is super-insulated, with krypton-filled triple-glazed windows, which means that you do not hear a sound inside. There is a monastic stillness in the house. The Vales designed a building which emitted no carbon dioxide. They also designed composting earth closets, lowered rainwater tanks into the cellar, and specified copper gutters to protect the drinking water. The house is cheap to build and inexpensive to run.

**
The camera can lie. Arthur Conan Doyle, creator of the Sherlock Holmes stories, believed himself to be a rational man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden setting and thought they were real. He published the photographs alongside an article he wrote, acknowledging fairies as supernatural wonders. It was not until 1939 that the two ladies who took the photos admitted these were fake. They simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and arranged them among flowers. The results are undeniably beautiful. But the simplicity of the trick undermines a basic principle of photography, that the camera cannot lie. From the moment cameras began capturing reality, that reality was being altered.

Throughout the ages, iron has been a powerful force in human imagination. Blacksmiths have been skilled craftsmen who have been admired for their work. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were highly respected and were often compared to doctors and astrologers. They have also been recognized as artists. In the eighteenth century, blacksmiths produced beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral and Art Nouveau architecture. However, the practice of blacksmithing had declined in Britain by the late 1960s due to heavy industry and the lack of demand for wrought-iron products. Recently, there has been a revival of blacksmithing thanks to increased interest in decorative architecture and a less conservative approach to interior design. The blacksmiths craft is being promoted through various events, including an exhibition of forged ironwork. The exhibition showcases a wide range of pieces, from bookends to a spiral staircase. Reserve prices start at PS90 and climb well into four figures. Many artists find the process of working with iron to be magical and rewarding. No other base metal can offer the same visual pleasure or sense of security.

The day I gave up smoking, I was pleased that everyone would be happy. But one of my colleagues was furious. She said, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I suppose my inability to explain how I had been a smoker for many years and how I had stopped four hours later was slightly irritating. The stop-smoking session was an interesting mixture of group therapy and hypnotherapy and it took place exactly two months and three weeks ago. I had not intended to stop and I did not even particularly want to. But I did stop. The physical craving and the pangs of desire for nicotine faded after a few days. I am increasingly coming to the view that smoking had a great deal to do with displacing boredom. Yes, I do miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Each 'new' experience as a non-smoker has to be addressed - eating out, waiting for an aeroplane, booking into a hotel, a theatre interval. All are key moments in which I would have previously smoked cigarettes.

Dorothy Hodgkin was a British woman scientist who won the Nobel prize in chemistry in 1964 for her work on penicillin and vitamin B12. She was also a mother of three and wife to a historian.
Hodgkin's most important successes were solving the structure of penicillin and vitamin B12. She pushed the technique into realms of complexity others deemed unreachable at the time.
There is much in Hodgkin's life of universal interest, but it would be disloyal of me to imply that this does not include the science itself. Scientific inquiry was the passion of Hodgkin's life.

Margaret Wilkins is said to have a 'sixth sense' that allows her to locate water. She can hold a forked hazel rod above the ground and detect water. She is increasingly in demand by farmers whose wells have dried up. Together with her husband, Margaret Wilkins runs a well-drilling business.
Margaret tries to locate water between 50 and 70 meters down. She uses a map of the area and a pendulum to find likely areas. Once she has identified the likely areas, she walks over the fields with a hazel stick. If there is water below, the stick rises up. If there is no water, the stick does not rise up.
Margaret Wilkins is not in isolation. Anthropologists and writers have long been fascinated by this inexplicable intuition. If she did not have this 'sixth sense', how else could the family live off their well-drilling business year after year?

**
We changed lives for a day! Have you ever dreamed about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Perhaps you think it would be more fun to do something quite different for a change. We fixed it for four people - read how it went.
A. Amanda's story I couldn't believe how dark and noisy it was at the restaurant. It was all a far cry from my home town and, to he honest, I wasn't sure I'd survive! Being a mother is definitely a busy job - but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks at shoulder height with one hand. The other waitresses made it look so simple, but just as I was getting the hang of it, the drinks started to slide off the tray and crashed on to the floor, splattering cocktails everywhere. I was so embarrassed, but all the other waitresses laughed.
B. Cindy's story I was feeling quite apprehensive about being a 'mum' for the day, but I was looking forward to it, too. As Amanda left to make her way to the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. But it was when I brought Sophie home from school that the real trouble started. They turned the settee into a trampoline and played a game which involved screaming as loudly as they possibly could. I decided to take the laid-back approach, imagining they'd soon get worn out. Wrong again. I thought I had a fair amount of stamina, but they beat me, hands down!
C. Rosemary's story On the farm, I have to get up early and sleep late. But I dithered for ages about how to look. There's so much to do before classes start again. I attended a staff meeting about reports and couldn't avoid getting roped in to help with athletics trials. Finally we moved on to the school hall for Physical Education. I was drained by now, but the children seemed to have inexhaustible energy.
D. Hilary's story I arrived at the farm early, but I discovered that Rosemary had been up for hours. The process of milking the cows took an exhausting two-and-a-half hours. And Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, seven days a week, 365 days a year! I found it quite a lonely day.

A trumpet is not just for Christmas. It is strange that many musicians, even leading ones, come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a musician who has established himself as unique among the world's trumpet-players today. He has a gift for finding the right compromise and making a relationship with the imperfections of the trumpet.
Hardenberger was born near Malmo, Sweden. He owes his career to the accident of a Christmas present when he was only eight. His father had the idea of giving his only son a trumpet. The success of the gift was instant. The boy never stopped playing.
Hardenberger has always thought of himself as a solo artist pure and simple. He had as a role-model the French trumpeter, Maurice Andre. He bought all his records, and idolised him. His parents gave him every chance to practise, and went along with his ambition to make trumpet-playing a career.
Hardenberger has a particular gift of communicating. He learned the pieces for the first round only, but he won through to the second. Luckily he already knew most of the pieces in that round too, but on getting through to the final he was faced with a concerto that had already daunted him. He didn't win first prize that time, but he enjoyed the performance.

New In Paperback A is a novel set in the fictional republic of Efica. The book is notable for its humour, unique vision, and penetrating psychological insight. It also follows the fortunes of one of the most isolated of the Scottish Orkney islands and its inhabitants over a long and uneventful rural history.
The book sets this narrative against pertinent moments in Scottish history. The author is skilled at exposing the haunting sadness that hovers beneath the seeming ordinariness of life. He is attuned more to the shadows than the bright lights of human activity and identifies the randomness of events.
The author uses startling images to convey her themes of memory and awareness. Those images are both alienating and illuminating.

Take Five Careers Rebecca Cripps meets five women who discuss their different professions. Each woman has a unique job and a unique set of challenges and rewards.
A. The Brain Surgeon
B. The Senior Designer
C. The Chauffeur
D. The Landscape Gardener
E. The Civil Engineer
Each woman describes her typical workday, including her morning routine, her work responsibilities, and her challenges and rewards. They also talk about their personal lives and their struggles to unwind.

**
Six people talk about their typical working day. Each person has a different job and responsibilities.
A. Credit Card Executive: Manages all customer development programmes for regular credit card users, including the launch and management of the Membership Rewards scheme.
B. Record Company Executive: Oversees the signing and production of artists, chooses songs and producers, and manages budgets and spending.
C. Sales Director: Deals with clients, sells furniture, and oversees restoration and accounts.
D. Air Traffic Controller: Works a set shift pattern, controls aircraft movements, and deals with a high volume of traffic.
E. Shop Manager: Helps customers, finds and orders books, and manages the point-of-sale system.
F. Financial Analyst: Provides financial risk assessments for multi-national companies, assesses financial risk, and travels to Africa to report on specific events.

Career Power Get the leading edge - motivate yourself to take full control at work.
A good leader is one who inspires, motivates, and encourages others. Leadership is not about height or intelligence. It's about making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are. To be a good leader, you should be able to speak out clearly and with conviction. You should also be able to motivate others and inspire them to believe in themselves.
Becoming a leader is recognizing your latent talents and developing them. It's also about setting goals and achieving them. If you want to be a successful leader, you need to be willing to take risks and learn from your mistakes. You also need to be able to communicate effectively and delegate tasks.
Whether you're the boss or a middle manager, you can benefit from improving your leadership skills. By following these tips, you can become a more effective leader and achieve your goals.

Films on video are a popular way to enjoy movies. There are many different types of films available on video, including action, comedy, drama, and horror. Some of the most popular films on video include A Abyss Long Before Titanic, The Thin Red Line, On Guard, Character, and The Good, the Bad and the Ugly.
A Abyss Long Before Titanic is a Cold War thriller about oil riggers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine stranded many miles beneath water. The film has a strong cast and impressive production design. However, the dialogue and characterisation are not as strong as the rest of the film.
The Thin Red Line is a war film about the battle for Guadalcanal. The film has a beautiful cast and impressive production design. However, the dialogue and characterisation are not as strong as the rest of the film.
On Guard is a swashbuckler film about a group of musketeers. The film has a strong cast and impressive production design. However, the dialogue and characterisation are not as strong as the rest of the film.
Character is a drama film about a bailiff and his son. The film has a strong cast and impressive production design. However, the dialogue and characterisation are not as strong as the rest of the film.
The Good, the Bad and the Ugly is a spaghetti western film about the post-Civil War West. The film has a strong cast and impressive production design. However, the dialogue and characterisation are not as strong as the rest of the film.

Steve Martin's Compelling Evidence is a compelling book. The narrator, a lawyer struggling to build a new practice, finds himself defending his boss's wife when she is tried for her husband's murder. The trial scenes are riveting, with the outcome in doubt right up to the verdict. This is a terrific book. Curtains for the Cardinal is a great book, but it is a bit long. File Under: Deceased introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, who is gutsy and versatile. Double Deuce is a high-quality entertainment book. False Prophet is an entertaining mystery. Blood Red, Snow White is a suspense novel that is well-written. Dead for a Ducat is a hilarious collection of characters. Fall Down Easy is Lawrence Gough's best book for some time.

At 34, Tim Pozzi decided to go backpacking. He quit his job and rented out his flat. He feels that he has taken charge of his life again. He is no longer in a relationship and has no burning career ambitions. He feels almost obliged to make the most of that freedom.
There are many reasons why people are travelling at this age. Some people want to have a final fling before settling down. Others want to temper their approach to life and get rid of their old patterns. Still others want to reassess their lives and take a step back.
If you're not happy doing what you're doing, it's no longer a question of just seeing it through. Now people are aware that opportunities exist and that a job isn't "for life" any more. Travel offers a chance to reassess, to take a step back and think about your life.

The computer has revolutionised the way I work and has made my life much easier. I used to work at a desk that was always a mess, but now I have a mini-office in a corner of the kitchen with everything I need to work from home. I can research stories, ask for further information, and discuss the pros and cons of working from home with people from all over the world. I also use spreadsheets to keep track of my income and expenses, and pre-formatted invoices and letterheads have saved me a lot of time and effort. However, there are also some challenges associated with working from home, such as isolation, distractions, and power struggles. Despite these challenges, I am grateful for the opportunity to work from home and I am confident that I can continue to build my career and achieve my goals.

The Tartan Museum is a modern museum in Scotland's capital, Edinburgh. It has a lot of interesting exhibits and a beautiful building. The museum is designed to be a pleasurable and visual experience for everyone, regardless of their prior knowledge.
The museum has a lot of different galleries and spaces. There are tall display cases and arrow-slit windows. There is also a Discovery Centre where children can learn about the museum's exhibits.
The museum has a temporary exhibition called the Twentieth Century gallery. It has a lot of objects that have been chosen by Scottish people and other personalities. The Prime Minister's suggestion was an electric guitar. Others went for televisions, thermos flasks and favourite toys.
Overall, the Tartan Museum is a beautiful and interesting museum. It is a must-see for anyone visiting Edinburgh.

The end of print may take some time. It's a pleasant word and a calming concept. Change may frighten some and challenge others, but transition means going surely and sweetly from somewhere present to somewhere future.
The latest print circulation figures show that sales are plummeting while visits to the same papers' websites keep on soaring. Sales in the West dropped back but Asia more than made up the difference. Books and magazines are also changing. Kindle and similar e-readers are booming, with sales up massively this year.
However, the decline in print sales is not as dramatic as some might think. Turn to the latest National Readership Survey figures and you'll find nearly 5,000,000 people aged between 15 and 35 following the main national dailies. And even within Europe, different countries have different stories to tell.
The best way of attracting a paying readership appears to be a deal that offers the print copy and digital access as some kind of joint package. And its advertising rates raise between nine and ten times more money than online.

People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A photograph with someone in it is usually more compelling than the same shot without the human interest. People are also the most difficult subjects to photograph well. To take a good picture of people, you need to be aware of actions, gestures and expressions. And often the presence of the camera itself can have a disastrous effect on these.
To photograph people well, you need to consider the following:
- Group people at different angles and distances.
- Help your subject relax and find a comfortable position.
- Make sure the subject is not overwhelmed by the background.
- Ask your subject to look into the lens.
- Use a background that is relevant to the subject.
- Show the interaction between people.
- Take pictures of people in their natural environment.
- Balance the subjects and the place they were visiting.
- Decide whether you want to pose or not pose your subject.

Sarah Janson is an artist who creates illusions of reality through her paintings. She is not interested in being recognized as a creator or genius artist. Instead, she focuses on the importance of the artwork itself. Janson has been painting trompe-l'oeil for sixteen years and has a string of major corporate and private commissions behind her. Much of her work is inspired by architecture or made for architectural settings.
Janson's paintings are unique and can be seen in a league of their own. They are often inspired by architecture and give the illusion that you can step into another room. However, there is also a danger with trompe-l'oeil that once you get the joke, your attention is lost.
Janson is generous in praise of her clients and is always willing to listen to their ideas. She is also very grateful for the clients who have let her loose on their walls.

In the modern workplace, emotional intelligence (EQ) is becoming increasingly important. It is the ability to monitor and regulate one's own and others' feelings, and to use feelings to guide thought and action. EQ comprises basic elements such as self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy and adeptness in social relationships.
More and more businesses are seeing that encouraging emotional intelligence skills is a valuable component of management philosophy. The less straightforward the job, the more emotional intelligence matters. If you have strong emotional intelligence skills, you are more likely to be successful in your job and in your personal life.
There are many examples of people who have risen to the top notwithstanding flaws in emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex and collaborative, companies where people work together best have a competitive edge. In the new workplace, with its emphasis on teamwork and a strong customer orientation, EQ is becoming increasingly essential for excellence in every job and in every part of the world.

**
Should the media earn money from content they don't own? Although digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to capture newsworthy events, social media has revolutionised citizen photography. With news regularly breaking on social networks, some journalists are now turning to them as sources of images as fast-moving events occur. Unfortunately, some reporters have published user-generated content (UGC) without permission. Despite official guidance that images posted on social media can be used without permission if there are exceptional circumstances or strong public interest, debate continues about whether this is ethical. With research indicating that around one in ten people would film or photograph a news event, it is clear that UGC has a major role to play in the future of the media. However, if the media is to prevent its relationship with the public from souring, steps must be taken to ensure that people are properly rewarded for their work and that permission is always sought.

**
Ancient Chinese medicine, also known as acupuncture, is a traditional Chinese system of medicine that includes herbalism, massage, diet, manipulation and exercise. It is used to treat many different conditions, but acupuncture's role in treating pain has received most attention in the West.
Acupuncture points are related to meridians, which are lines of energy flow through the body. There are over three hundred points on the main meridians, with hundreds more elsewhere that are used less often.
Acupuncture can be used to treat a variety of pain conditions, including back pain, spots injuries, arthritis, headaches and migraine. It is also used to treat post-operative pain, menstrual pain, facial nerve pain and pain suffered by terminally ill people.
Acupuncture is a safe and effective treatment for pain, but it is important to note that it is not a cure. It is important to consult with a medical doctor before making any decisions about acupuncture.

P. D. James, a best-selling crime writer, is known for her intricate and brilliant imagination. She exudes an air of quiet authority, but it is soon apparent that she is actually shy. She has written 12 major detective novels that are read avidly by millions worldwide. She is a great fan of the works of close friend Ruth Rendell and enjoys reading detective stories.
James was born in Oxford and grew up mainly in Cambridge. She worked full-time in administration for the National Health Service and made good use of her organizational skills. She became 'quite accustomed' to seeing corpses while working in forensic science. But it was not fascination with death itself that inspired her. It was the shape and construction involved in the writing of a crime novel that appealed to her.
James believes that writing detective stories is a way of bringing order out of disorder. The solution of a crime confirms the sanctity of life, even if that life is unlovable. Nobody really likes violence.

The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is accepted as a genuine science in many countries. It can be used to indicate certain illnesses, such as heart disease and cancer, and can reveal psychological states and emotional disturbances. Graphology can also be used for vocational guidance and as an adjunct to interviews.
Handwriting can reveal other psychological characteristics, such as deviousness, intelligence, and confidence. It can also be used to predict would-be suicides and other serious problems. However, there is little hard evidence to support such claims. Some psychiatrists are highly critical of them.

Is your office working ok? Fresh air and comfortable chairs are the key to a happy, healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We went to four contrasting offices to find out how healthy and happy they were as working environments. On our expert panel were a building health consultant; an ergonomist, who studies people's working conditions; and an occupational psychologist. Here are their verdicts. Office A. This office is simple but has a lot of natural light. The air quality is good and the employees are happy. Office B. This office is comfortable and well-maintained. The air quality is good and the employees are satisfied with their work environment. Office C. This office is very busy and has a lot of natural light. The air quality is good and the employees are well-served by technology. Office D. This office is very dusty and has a lot of problems with the air conditioning. The employees are stressed and driven by deadlines. The company needs to adopt a policy of team-working.

Chewing gum is a popular fashion accessory in the United States, where people chew an average of 12 million sticks a day. Gum is made from a variety of ingredients, including pine resins, softeners, and flavourings. The ancient Greeks chewed a gum-like resin obtained from the bark of the mastic tree. American colonists followed the example of the Amero-Indians and chewed the resin that formed on spruce trees. Modern chewing gum has its origins in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance obtained from the sapodilla tree. Gum made from this resulted in a smoother, more satisfying and more elastic chew. Today, the chewing gum market has grown, and manufacturers have turned to synthetics to reduce costs and meet demands.

The Ghanerao Hotel in India, the Hermitage Hotel in New Zealand, the Paradis Hotel on Mauritius, the Ladera Hotel in St. Lucia, and the Splendid Hotel in Istanbul are five charming hotels. Each hotel offers a unique and unforgettable experience.
The Ghanerao Hotel is a peaceful retreat nestled amidst the Aravalli Hills. It blends English country-house tranquility with Indian symbolism. The Hermitage Hotel is situated in the breathtaking countryside, offering stunning views of glaciers and mountains. The Paradis Hotel is isolated on its own peninsula, surrounded by pristine beaches and turquoise waters. The Ladera Hotel is known for its dramatic setting and colonial style. The Splendid Hotel is a historic gem, steeped in glamour and history.
These hotels provide a perfect escape from the hustle and bustle of daily life. They offer a chance to relax, unwind, and immerse oneself in the beauty of their surroundings. Whether you're seeking tranquility, adventure, or a touch of luxury, these charming hotels are sure to provide an unforgettable experience.

The hotel inspector Sue Brown judges hotels for a living. One day, she was inspecting the Globe Hotel. Things were not going well from the beginning. The receptionist was reciting room rates over the phone to a potential guest, but she was not aware of the identity of the real guest. Sue was not impressed by the hotel's poor service and condition. She found out that the hotel was rated among the top 130 of the 4,000 listed in the hotel guide. However, there were some problems with the hotel. The access from the car park was via an unmanned door, and the corridor to the hotel entrance was long and deserted. The receptionist announced that there was no record of the booking, and one of the rooms was unoccupied. Sue found that the room was stuffy and had a gaping panel in the wardrobe. She also found a large hole in the wall. Despite all of the problems, Sue was able to negotiate with the general manager to get some things fixed. She was also able to get the hotel to provide a better service.

Seven Up Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experience of conquering the highest peak on each continent, the Seven Summits. My quest to climb the Seven Summits came late in life. I climbed the Seven Summits in the order I completed them.
A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)
I was in a snow cave below the summit when I started talking to my feet. The cold was getting into my feet and I recalled other climbers who had lost fingers and toes from frostbite.
B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)
This mountain is regarded as the most treacherous in the world. We followed a new route and spent the third night on a windswept ridge.
C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,89Sm)
We got lost in the dense jungles and ran out of water. We found a rock pool and attempted to climb the breach wall, but prudently retired.
D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)
The original route up Aconcagua is little more than a walk. We decided to miss out on the glacier and go across the north ridges.
E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)
When I learned that climbing Vinson Massif was just a matter of guiding enough people, attempting all of the Seven Summits became a reality.
F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)
We crossed open slopes and reached the summit. But we found there was another kilometre-long ridge to the actual summit.
G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)
We climbed in rock shoes and reached the summit. I was given a standing ovation on this, my seventh summit. Mission accomplished!
